awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Innovative Jarvis Undergraduate Mathematics Program (I-JUMP):  Embedding Computational and Mathematical Biology into Life STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Jarvis Christian College will promote and expose the interface between computational and applied mathematics and Life STEM and build capacities in the learning, teaching, and research of under-represented minority students in cutting edge computational and applied mathematics tools, techniques and concepts applicable for biology. The project activities will provide professional development for faculty, increase recruitment, student retention and graduation rates and provide pathways for minority students to pursue graduate study and careers in computation and mathematical biology. 

The project objectives of the I-JUMP project are 1) to enrich the mathematics curriculum by embedding cutting edge computational and mathematical biology tools, techniques, and concepts into the mathematics courses; 2) to improve teaching strategy through converging differentiated instruction with cutting edge technology to engage the students in learning new concepts; 3) to expand students? visibilities and competencies in computational and mathematical biology research via infusion of computational and mathematical biology research into the existing undergraduate research curricula,  research internships, and peer-mentored research and 4) to update teaching and research infrastructure to support the new teaching strategies and the inquiry, project and research-based courses in computational and mathematical biology and mathematics general education courses. The outcomes of the project will embed the concepts of mathematical biology into every student's education at Jarvis Christian College. The training and knowledge in mathematical biology will provide graduates with the critical thinking, collaboration, creativity, and communication skills that will benefit them in their selected career pathways. Moreover, the project will create opportunities for minority and underrepresented students to participate in undergraduate research, pursue graduate study, and provide a pathway to careers in computational biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Jarvis Christian College, known as the Innovative Jarvis Undergraduate Mathematics Program (I-JUMP), aimed to promote and expose the interface between computational and applied mathematics and Life STEM. It sought to build capacities in the learning, teaching, and research of under-represented minority students in cutting-edge computational and applied mathematics tools, techniques, and concepts applicable to biology.

Intellectual Merit:

The I-JUMP project enriched the mathematics curriculum by embedding advanced computational and mathematical biology tools, techniques, and concepts into mathematics courses. Notably, the traditional Calculus course was redesigned into Biocalculus to better align with biological applications. Additionally, new courses were developed, including "Introduction to Computational and Mathematical Biology in Python" and "Applications of Parallel Super Computing for Life STEM." These courses fostered a deeper understanding of mathematical biology among students, equipping them with critical thinking, collaboration, creativity, and communication skills essential for their future careers. The project also improved teaching strategies by converging differentiated instruction with cutting-edge technology, engaging students in learning new concepts effectively.

Broader Impacts:

The project had a significant impact on both the student body and the broader community. By embedding computational and mathematical biology into the Life STEM curriculum, I-JUMP attracted a diverse group of students, including those from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM. The hands-on, interdisciplinary approach increased student engagement, retention, and graduation rates. Additionally, the project provided professional development for faculty, enhancing their ability to teach interdisciplinary courses. It also established pathways for minority students to pursue graduate study and careers in computational and mathematical biology.

Outcomes:

  1. Curriculum Development: Successfully integrated computational and mathematical biology into the Life STEM curriculum through new courses and modules, including the redesign of Calculus to Biocalculus and the creation of new courses such as "Introduction to Computational and Mathematical Biology in Python" and "Applications of Parallel Super Computing for Life STEM."
  2. Faculty Development: Conducted workshops and training sessions for faculty to enhance their ability to teach interdisciplinary courses.
  3. Student Engagement: Increased student enrollment, retention, and graduation rates in STEM programs, particularly among underrepresented groups.
  4. Community Outreach: Established partnerships with local educational institutions to promote STEM education and career pathways.
  5. Research and Publications: Produced several research papers and presentations at national conferences, including the publication "Challenges and opportunities to build quantitative self-confidence in biologists" in BioScience (Cuddington et al., 2023).
  6. Summer Programs: Conducted two summer programs: the Summer Enrichment Program (SEP) in Computational and Mathematical Biology for high school students and first- and second-year students from Jarvis Christian University and the University of Texas at Tyler and Austin, with 20 participants. Additionally, the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) in Computational and Mathematical Biology engaged 20 junior and senior students in Mathematics, Biology, and Chemistry, providing hands-on research opportunities and fostering early interest in STEM careers.
  7. Student Aspirations: Following their participation in the undergraduate research experience, many students in biology and chemistry expressed a strong interest in pursuing a minor in mathematics, highlighting the program's success in sparking interdisciplinary academic pursuits.
  8. Presentations: The Principal Investigator (PI) gave oral presentations at the Joint Mathematics Meeting, SMB Meeting, BEER Symposium, Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM), and the National Association of Mathematicians (NAM); and poster presentations at ICERM, ImageXD, and Predictive Modeling in Biology and Medicine, showcasing the project's findings and contributing to the broader academic community.
  9. Professional Memberships: The PI joined several professional organizations to further the project’s goals and stay connected with the broader scientific community. These memberships include the Society for Mathematical Biology (SMB) with subgroups on Cardiovascular Modeling, Developmental Biology, Education, Immunobiology and Infection, Mathematical Epidemiology, Mathematical Oncology, Mathematics Neuroscience, Methods for Biological Modeling, and Population Dynamics Ecology & Evolution; the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) with Activity Groups on Applied Mathematics Education, Computational Science and Engineering, Data Science, and Life Sciences; the Mathematical Association of America (MAA) with SIGMAA groups on Mathematical and Computational Biology, Undergraduate Research, Research in Undergraduate Mathematics Education, and Mathematicians in Business, Industry, and Government; and the American Mathematical Society (AMS); and NAM.
  10. Student Career Progression: Many students who participated in the program have continued their careers and graduate studies in STEM fields, demonstrating the program's effectiveness in inspiring and preparing students for advanced academic and professional pursuits.

Overall, the I-JUMP project has made significant strides in preparing students for the interdisciplinary nature of modern STEM careers. By fostering a collaborative learning environment and providing practical, hands-on experiences, the program has equipped students with the skills and knowledge necessary to succeed in the rapidly evolving field of computational and mathematical biology. 


Last Modified: 10/20/2024
Modified by: Widodo Samyono
